Let $A\subseteq \mathbb{N}$ be an infinite set such that $\lvert A\cap \{1,\ldots,N\}\rvert=o(N)$. Is it true that\[\limsup_{N\to \infty}\frac{\lvert (A+A)\cap \{1,\ldots,N\}\rvert}{\lvert A\cap \{1,\ldots,N\}\rvert}\geq 3?\]



Erd\H{o}s writes it is 'easy to see' that this holds with $3$ replaced by $2$, and that $3$ would be best possible here. We do not see an easy argument that this holds with $2$, but this follows e.g. from the main result of Mann \cite{Ma60}.

The answer is yes, proved by Freiman \cite{Fr73}.

See also [899] for the difference set analogue.

This problem has been formalised in Lean as part of the Google DeepMind Formal Conjectures project.




References


[Fr73] Fre\u{\i}man, G. A., Foundations of a structural theory of set addition. (1973), vii+108.

[Ma60] Mann, H. B., A refinement of the fundamental theorem on the density of the sum of two sets of integers. Pacific J. Math. (1960), 909-915.
